summary.content: Let us speak plainly: what is good? All that heightens the feeling of power, the will to power, the power itself in man. What is evil? All that comes from weakness. The Antichrist is not a devil, but a thinker who unmasks the highest lies. Christianity—the greatest lie. Not error, not illusion, but willful reversal of all natural values. I write for the strong, not the meek—for those ready to transvalue all values, to sweep away the dust of millennia.

Christianity is a metaphysics of the hangman. It denies life, exalts weakness, glorifies suffering, and sanctifies failure. It is a religion of decadence—born from resentment, spread by deceit. It poisons the strong with pity, turns the proud into sinners, and teaches man to despise the very instincts that make him noble. It is not moral; it is mortal—it infects vitality like a slow disease, clothed in virtue.

Pity is the tool of decay. It preserves the weak, protects failure, and multiplies suffering. Pity negates life, because life is struggle, selection, growth through hardship. Christianity turns pity into a virtue—and thereby makes weakness contagious. We must unlearn pity, not because we are cruel, but because we are honest. Let the diseased perish: that is nature’s way. And let us not weep for it.

Christianity inverts all noble values. Pride becomes sin. Strength becomes cruelty. Pleasure becomes guilt. And in place of a free, vital, noble man, it offers the slave: obedient, humble, terrified of his own instincts. This is the moral revolution of the weak, who, unable to rise above, turn downward and call it elevation. They make 'heaven' a reward for submission and 'hell' a punishment for passion. This inversion is the true Fall of Man.

Jesus of Nazareth was not a redeemer—he was an anarchist of the soul. He preached weakness, peace, turning the other cheek. He dissolved all natural bonds of power and hierarchy. He was not killed because he sinned, but because he was irrelevant to the instincts of life. His 'kingdom' was no-world, an inner dream-world of love and submission. In truth, he died too soon. It was Paul who resurrected the lie—turning a rebel mystic into the crucified God, birthing the Church on the grave of truth.

The Church is not holy—it is a fortress of falsehood. It survives not by faith, but by control. It hates knowledge, fears inquiry, and silences thought. It has persecuted philosophers, mutilated science, and crushed joy. It preaches celibacy and poverty while hoarding power and gold. Its saints are freaks, its martyrs are liars, and its heaven is a bribe. The Church has stood against every noble instinct man has had—and it has called that victory 'God’s will.'

Sin is the greatest fraud in history. A fabrication. A tool to enslave the soul. Christianity teaches man he is broken by nature, born guilty, in need of salvation. But what is 'sin'? The natural instincts: desire, anger, ambition. Christianity makes man hate himself for being alive. This invented burden is how the priest gains power. To sell salvation, one must first create the disease. I say: there is no sin—only life denied.

Christianity is not the will to truth—it is the will to nothingness. It prefers a world without joy, without conflict, without life itself, rather than a world that does not obey its fantasies. Its paradise is a negation of the earth. It deifies suffering, demands sacrifice, and calls the end of instincts 'spirituality.' But behind this will is hatred—hatred of life, of reality, of strength. The Christian wants the world to end, so he can be proven right.

Rome was strong, proud, full of grandeur. Jerusalem was resentful, bitter, cunning. When Rome fell to Christianity, it was the victory of the worm over the lion. The Jews created the slave revolt in morality—Christianity was its sequel. Paul, the true founder, took the weapon of guilt and wielded it against the aristocracy of instinct. In this war, Jerusalem triumphed—but what was gained? A thousand years of darkness and decline.

I call for a new table of values. One based on strength, affirmation, beauty, and greatness. Away with the moral lie of sin and salvation. Away with pity, meekness, and the will to weakness. Let us reclaim the instincts, the earth, the flesh. Let us affirm life—not as a test or a prelude—but as the highest reality. The future belongs to the noble soul, who creates values, commands, laughs, and loves fate. The Antichrist is not a destroyer—he is a re-creator.

I write not for everyone. I write for the strong, the solitary, the life-affirmers. My words are fire for the ice of Christian morality. The greatest sin is not pride, but submission. The greatest lie is not heresy, but faith. Let us burn the old tablets and dance on their ashes. We are not sinners—we are creators. We are not fallen—we are rising. Let there be a new dawn, beyond guilt, beyond God—beyond good and evil.
